cat

Once upon a time, I had a cat, I had ten dollars, I would buy it food for eight dollars, bathe it often, and it was very sticky to me.

Later, I took it out to play, passers-by thought it was cute, they fed it cat food, ham sausage, I was very unhappy because it was mine. I wanted to carry it home, but he broke away from me and meowed at the person who gave it good food, I hugged him a few times and he didn't go with me, and scratched me, so I turned around and left.....

Later, I came across it by chance on the road, and it was dirty. Passers-by will only give it good food and play with it, but they will not take it home and bathe it. It saw me and followed me home, I shut it out, it meowed outside the door, it was very uncomfortable,
but I wouldn't want it anymore
.

Disgusting F2P tactics deviating from the original OW formula in order to appeal to the 12yo Fortnite fanbase that can only afford "free" games while begging their parents for their credit card in order to buy ridiculously expensive skins and dances.

[b]There is absolutely no upgrade from the original OW.[/b] Everything looks and feels the same. They just slapped "2" next to the name as a marketing strategy because they decided to make the game F2P after the player-base died. I paid 60$ for OW1 and they removed it, so for owners of OW1 this is absolutely not a free game. We paid for it, and now we are forced to pay again through their awful and predatory battle-pass system if we want to get something as simple as an Emote.

Everything is now locked behind ridiculous grinding and absurd weekly "challenges" that ask you to invest hours upon hours to complete them because they are based on luck (e.g., get 20 team kills). You need to pay 20 euro for a skin-recolor, or farm for 8 MONTHS to get it for "free." The supposed "free" rewards from the Battle-pass are joke-sprays and useless voice-lines. All the real things are locked behind the premium pay-wall that, upon completion, doesn't even give you your money/currency back (to invest it in the next Battle-pass). Essentially you need a bi-monthly subscription to play the game, as there is nothing to strive for in the "free" part of the Battle-pass.

The new "free" players that joined are entirely oblivious to FPSs and make games very frustrating. They cannot DPS, they cannot flank, they cannot heal. They pick Moira and play her like its Call of Duty. The awful matchmaking system pairs these new users with existing veterans, making each match a steamroll. You either get destroyed and can't even leave the spawn room, or you entirely destroy the enemy team. There is no in-between. This makes games frustrating as you can lose 10 games in a row just like that.

Overall, a disgusting re-release by Blizzard/Activision/Microsoft (or whatever company they sold themselves to nowadays). They turned a paid-game into a Freemium cow ready to be milked before it dies under the pretense that this is some sort of "update" or a big "overhaul."

You can tell the game is dying by the mere fact that they brought this to Steam for a quick player-injection.

I have 485 hours in Overwatch 2 and received all of the achievements I earned from launching the game via steam. I have not played OW2 since Blizzard announced they were no longer going to deliver on the original vision promised to the community. This upgrade was the entire reason behind Overwatch 2's entire existence, however it's been made painfully clear that the only purpose behind the change was to turn Overwatch into a live service game with egregious amounts of monetization.

The main issue with this is that in Blizzard fashion, they shut down the original Overwatch, which was a paid game, for this. Then somehow managed to make the worst and most greedy monetization system in the business. In Overwatch the only monetization was loot boxes and despite the fact that they contained a lot of worthless filler no one wanted, the system was at least generous by giving the player a loot box for just playing where you could also receive coins to buy whatever you really wanted if you got duplicates and despite how much everyone hated loot boxes, they hate this new system even more.

In Overwatch 2, there's a battlepass with no earnable premium currency for both free and premium passes like every other game out there with a battlepass system. You can 'earn' a small sliver of the premium currency by playing the game and doing challenges but it's a fixed amount and again, very small, it would take months to unlock anything through that method. They do give you "Legacy Coins" which can be used to purchase cosmetics from Overwatch but no new ones. The amount you get is not really generous either and they raised the cost of cosmetics by an obscene amount. It is in no way shape or form a good deal to buy premium currency for these skins which cost $20 each so your only decent option to get cosmetics is via the battlepass but the problem there is you're just earning the exact same thing everyone else is. These cosmetics also seem to be Blizzards number one priority and some turn out horrendously ugly. They churn them out quickly for every new battlepass.

There are three roles in the game: Tank, DPS, and Support.
Most people play DPS, then Tank, then Support. Tanks are bullet sponges that do less damage as one would expect, Supports are a little too strong in my opinion and being that it's the least popular role, most of the people that do play Support focus more on getting kills like a DPS than healing because they wanted to play DPS and even though they're the only ones that can consistently heal others. DPS does feel a bit underwhelming, like they don't do as much damage as you'd expect and can be overwhelmed by Supports due to their own damage output and abilities, Tanks too obviously.

Now onto the gameplay experience, it's mostly frustrating. Overwatch pretty much always has been about appealing to the more competitive playerbase and while the original development team dragged their feet when it came to balance, the new team is just unbelievably incompetent and have no idea what they're doing. That's coming from someone that derives enjoyment from playing to win so I myself have a competitive mindset. In Overwatch, my favorite characters were Mei and Sombra because they were the most fun characters to play. In Overwatch 2 they nerfed the most entertaining part of Mei and made her boring and they've already slated Sombra to be nerfed in the same way. But do they balance the character that in my opinion is the most broken one and has been since the original game, being Junkrat? Nope.

Competitive mode is not enjoyable, if you're solo you'll likely be abused by your teammates who are in groups or squads and if you call them out for it they'll probably just straight up throw the whole game. Also due to squads existing, many players perform poorly because they're boosted from playing in a squad so they're not at the level for the Rank they're playing in and you can only have two in a squad in the higher Ranks. They don't like it if you play certain characters and they'll let you know, even if they have no idea how to play the character themselves. Very toxic. Some are likely to be smurfs as well. OW2 does have a league for esports but I believe they're going to be shutting it down, probably because it's not profitable enough and the company's surrounded by controversy.

The new characters they introduce will likely be broken as in overpowered so the battlepass will sell more. Yes, new characters are locked behind the battlepass system. If you don't unlock the character before the battlepass ends you can 'earn' the character by completing some challenges.

There are also events during holidays like Christmas, Halloween, Summer, Chinese new year, etc. but they do feel a bit underwhelming, the challenges take too long are not very fun to complete, the 'new' event gameplay is not fun to play and the rewards are usually lackluster. They do recycle old content as well, so if you didn't like it the first time, you get to not like it a second, and third time and so on. Halloween is usually my favorite time of year but after getting Junkenstein over and over, I never looked forward to it.

I would not recommend this game. Blizzard is not the same company it used to be when it made good games. Now it's all about the money.

Overwatch 2 has failed to live up to the expectations set by its predecessor. The lack of innovation, underwhelming single-player experience, questionable monetization strategy, and technical problems collectively contribute to a disappointing sequel. While there's still potential for improvement through updates and patches, as it stands, Overwatch 2 falls short of delivering the engaging and captivating experience that fans had hoped for.
